headline: Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine delays three executions, citing problems obtaining lethal drugs
author: Eric Lagatta
sentences:
Death penalty in question: Growing number of Republican lawmakers support ending the death penalty in Ohio
The governor's office said in a statement the move is "due to ongoing problems involving the willingness of pharmaceutical suppliers to provide drugs to the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction ... without endangering other Ohioans."

He delayed more executions after The Dispatch reported on methods that state officials were using to obscure the sources of execution drugs in the face of strong objections by manufacturers to the use of their products in the Ohio death chamber.

The execution dates for the men are on a three-year hold after DeWine announced lethal injection — the state's only method for carrying out a death sentence — isn't possible because pharmaceutical companies have not sold drugs for this purpose.
Mike DeWine on Friday delayed the executions of three men that were scheduled for this summer, citing the state's ongoing difficulty in obtaining the lethal drugs needed to put them to death.

The three latest executions to be delayed are:
Percy Hutton, a Cleveland man convicted in 1985 of murdering a man who he accused of stealing a sewing machine.
As an incoming governor in early 2019, DeWine delayed his first execution after a federal judge sitting in Dayton compared Ohio's execution method to torture.

Mike DeWine responds 'I didn't say that'
Eric Lagatta is a reporter at the Columbus Dispatch covering public safety, breaking news and social justice issues.
A judge sentenced Hutton to death in 1986, and the Ohio Supreme Court last set Hutton's execution date in September 2017 for June 22.
Cedric Carter, of Cincinnati, who murdered a United Dairy Farmers convenience store clerk during a robbery in 1992.
Douglas Coley, who was awaiting a July 20 execution for the 1997 murder of Samar El-Okdi, of Toledo.
The new date of Hutton's execution has been moved to June 18, 2025.
DeWine's stance: Described as a death penalty supporter, Ohio Gov.
Coley's new date of execution has been moved to Sept. 24, 2025.
DeWine moved Carter's execution date to Aug. 27, 2025.
Carter was scheduled to be executed on Aug. 24.
